newsitem.title: GREECE: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK FINANCIAL NEWS - APRIL 9.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK FINANCIAL NEWS - APRIL 9.

text.p: Leading stories in the Greek financial press:
KATHIMERINI

--Despite concerns over stalled public renenues, the government yesterday admitted that a new increase in taxation would not solve the problem and that efforts for fiscal adjustment will from now in centre on cutbacks in state spending.

--Ergobank has expressed interest in the sale of state-run Bank of Central Greece and is soon expected to submit a bid, sources say. Others interested in the sale are Egnatia, Bank of Piraeus, Bank of Cyprus, Eurobank and Canada's Nova Scotia.
--The Post Office Savings Bank is expected to issue 65 billion drachmas of housing loans to 6,500 civil servants this year.

--The Capital Market Commission is expanding its inquiry of brokerage companies, examining procedures involved in the purchase of state titles on the behalf of institutional investors and insurance companies.
IMERISIA

--The government is now centring on corrective measures for the economy as major discrepancies in real and forecast tax revenues continue to be a source of concern, despite encouraging economic indicators. At the Economist roundtable with the Greek government, the need for more realism in investments has been noted.
--The beginning of social dialogue has been postponed to after May 1, following adverse reaction from both within the government's ranks and unionists, including those aligned to ruling party PASOK.

--The new president of conservative opposition New Democracy Costas Karamanlis expanded on his party's economic policies at last night's address to the Economist conference. Karamanlis stressed the need for lower taxes, a smaller and more effective state and incentives for business.
KERDOS
--The government's positions on a new focus for the labour market has caused intense concern within the government itself, forcing a reappraisal of the proposed measures to avert industrial action.

--Greek businesses should turn their interest to the Balkans to reduce their operating costs and become more competitive, rather than asking for more incentives from the Greek government, Deputy Development Minister Anna Diamantopoulos says.
NAFTEMBORIKI

--The negative image so far of the course of public revenues will change in the next few months with the implementation of the new taxation code and with the beginning of the operation of the special economic crimes squad SDOE as of tomorrow, National Economy and Finance Minister Yannos Papandoniou and Deputy Finance Minister George Drys said yesterday.

--Citibank posted a 20.0 percent increase in net profits in 1996. This year, the US bank expects profits to continue at the same rate and will open two new branches in Greece and continue to place emphasis on consumer banking.
EXPRESS

--There's tension between taxation department officials and the leadership of the finance ministry over the discouraging returns from the implementation of taxation policies. A government source said taxation officials were meddling in policy and personnel decisions and that a solution was desperately needed.

--The Communist Party of Greece-aligned unionists have stepped away from the General Confederation of Workers of Greece (GSEE), saying they will celebrate Labour Day on their own in protest at the GSEE's stand on labour issues.

--Prime Minister Costas Simitis will visit the development ministry on Monday to discuss tourism with Development Minister Vasso Papandreou. Today, he will visit the labour ministry following yesterday's meeting with Minister Miltiades Papaioannou. --Maria Petrakis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4
